awd_titl_txt: Nuclear, Particle, and Weak Interaction Physics of the Big Bang and Stellar Collapse
awd_abstract_narration:
The research supported in this project will provide insights into how atomic nuclei and elementary particles and radiation behave in extreme conditions of temperature and density. The PI will leverage these insights to provide important clues about the nature of elementary particles, the mysterious neutrinos in particular, and about how the elements are synthesized in nature, e.g., the heaviest elements in the fiery interiors of collapsing stars or colliding neutron stars, and the lightest in the first seconds in the early universe.  In turn, these considerations can give us insight into new physics. The calculations to be done in this project will involve honing humanity's fundamental theory of nature, i.e., Quantum Mechanics, into a tool capable of modeling the behavior of neutrinos in the extreme environments provided by the cosmos. Another key product of this Project will be the training of young nuclear physicists, at both the graduate and undergraduate levels. 

The research supported in this Project will be directed toward probing the fundamental physics of neutrinos and nuclei by exploiting the intersection of exciting new developments in nuclear physics and neutrino physics on the one hand, with the explosion of new data and insights from the advent of multi-messenger astronomy and precision cosmology on the other. A key issue in this enterprise will be studying how neutrinos interact in dense matter and how these interactions may cause neutrinos to change their flavors (e.g., electron type neutrinos changing to tau type and vice versa). This is a fiercely nonlinear problem because neutrino flavor/spin determines how neutrinos interact, and how they interact determines how flavors/spin change. To these ends, the P.I. and his graduate and undergraduate students will work toward: (1) Understanding and modeling the quantum kinetic equations which govern neutrino flavor and spin evolution in a general medium; (2) Constructing large-scale numerical simulations of neutrino flavor/spin evolution in the early universe and compact object environments and assessing the feedback of this neutrino flavor physics on the prospects for the synthesis of nuclei in these sites, and the implications of this physics for multi-messenger observations and dark sector physics; (3) Understanding nuclear structure, neutrino-nucleus interactions, nuclear partition functions, and nuclear weak strength distributions in high temperature environments.

This project advances the objectives of "Windows on the Universe: the Era of Multi-Messenger Astrophysics", one of the 10 Big Ideas for Future NSF Investments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded project, "Nuclear, Particle, and Weak Interaction Physics of the Big Bang and Stellar Collapse", enabled exploration of the science surrounding the physics of fundamental particles and atomic nuclei, the cosmic origin of the elements, the earliest history of the universe, and the extreme environments and violent deaths of stars far more massive than the sun.

In fact, the research performed in this project established connections between these seemingly quite different topics. These connections led to deeper insights into both fundamental nuclear and elementary particle physics on the one hand, and exotic sites and processes in the universe on the other. Brokering these connections can help levearge the experimental and theoretical progress in terrestrial laboratories to better understand how the very early universe works and how massive stars explode or produce neutron stars and black holes. Likewise, it also works the other way. The exciting recent discoveries of astronomy and astrophysics that stem from new observatories and new ways of looking at the universe,  like gravitational waves, can be leveraged into new insights into fundamental nuclear and elementary particle physics. These insights can be complementary to those derived from terrestrial laboratories, but in some cases they provide our only means of addressing the fundamental physics of nuclei and particles.

Specifically in this project, a key focus was on the properties and behaviors of the ghost-like neutrinos. These particles interact with atoms and atomic nuclei extremely weakly, making terrestrial experimental probes difficult. Despite this, in recent years experiments have revealed much about these particles. However, we know that there are many properties of these particles that remain mysterious and are extremely hard or likelly impossible to measure in the laboratory.

This project provided ways to use environments in the cosmos to study some of these outstanding questions about neutrinos. This is possible because, perhaps surprisingly, neutrinos carry most of the energy in the early universe (e.g., when it is of order 1 second in age or younger) and in the collapsing cores of massive stars.  Neutrinos come in three varieties (or "flavors") and these determine how they interact with matter.

But neutrinos have a neat trick. As they propagate through a medium in the early universe and in a collapsing star they can change their flavor. This is important because neutrino flavor affects the way these particles transport and deposit energy and the way they influence the ratio of neutrons and protons --- and energy deposition and this neutron-proton ratio are key determinants of how astrophysical sites produce heavy elements (like gold or uranium for example from stellar collapse/supernovae or light elemnts like helium in tthe early universe). Establishing this connection between neutrino physics and the origin of the elements is, however, fraught. The reason is that when the neutrinos propagate through a medium that contains other neutrinos, the flavor transformation problem becomes very difficult and nonlinear -- the way a neutrino changes its flavor depends on the flavor states of all the other neutrinos it encounters! The research in this project made advances in understranding how to calculate this process. In turn, those advances, together with modeling of neutrino interactions with atomic nuclei, allow us to better understand the exotic environments in the cosmos that give rise to neutron stars and black holes. Better understanding of the way neutrinos influence the physics of the early universe and collapsing massive stars enabled probes of, and constraints on, proposed neutrino properties like "secret" interactions among these particles. These would be difficult or impossible to find in a terrestrial laboratory, but can show up in these environments in the cosmos that have huge numbers of neutrinos. This is especially true when the neutrinos leave a "fossil record" of their influence on the synthesis of elements. 

The research in this project served as a training ground for junior scientists at all levels: undergraduate and graduate students in particular, but also postdoctoral scientists. For example, four of the PI's Physics graduate students at UCSD completed their PhD theses during the funding period of this project. Likewise, the PI and his graduate students worked with a diverse set of undergraduate students.

Additionally, the PI gave many talks and seminars. Several of these were directed toward students, and sometimes given to general audiences. A key objective of science communication, like that done in this project, is to fire the imaginations of young people and to keep the tax-paying public aprised of the fruits of their investment in the scientific enterprise.
